(Queen says no to pot-smoking FBI members)

This line comes from the recording of “Too Bad About Sorrows”, a song recorded during the Get Back Sessions (eventually renamed Let It Be) that was never actually included on the final cut of the album.

Lennon was becoming increasingly frustrated and bored with the recording of the song, and exclaimed the line out of sheer procrastination.

Producer Phil Spector had engineered a loop using the song’s instrumental break, over which he inserted snippets of speech from the Let It Be film soundtrack. However, he ended up discarding this idea completely, leaving only this piece of Lennon dialogue.

Acclaimed Beatles biographer, Mark Lewisohn, acknowledges in his piece The Complete Beatles Recording Sessions that this technique was common in the rough mixes for the track:

Several mixes were made in this fashion, utilising such cinéma vérité moments from the rooftop performance element of the film as the old woman’s “I just can’t see that it makes sense!”, the young girl’s “Yeah, I think it’s great… livens up the office hours, anyway”, the bowler-hatted vicar’s “Nice to have something for free in this country at the moment, isn’t it?”, the taxi driver’s “Is it their new record? Oh, great, I’m all in favour of it!” and the pompous businessman’s “This type of music is all right in its place, it’s quite enjoyable. But I think it’s a bit of an imposition to absolutely disrupt all the business in this area…”

Whilst “Too Bad About Sorrows” as a whole was not included on the final album, this part of it is the only piece of music recorded at Twickenham Film Studios, as well as the only part of the song, to be included on the record.

A reference to Chuck Berry’s “Johnny B Goode”, one of the most famous early rock-and-roll songs. Berry was a big influence on The Beatles.

Here, John Lennon is playing slide guitar. George is trying to encourage Lennon, who was aware of his limitations on the instrument and would have preferred Harrison to play it.

Of course, Lennon has the same first name as Goode… which would cause Berry to make a cringeworthy pun when the two of them performed “Johnny B. Goode” together

Johnny… let’s be good.
(Elmore James got nothing on this, baby)

Elmore James was an American blues guitarist, particularly known for his slide guitar playing.



Unusually, John Lennon played slide guitar on this track. Normally, Harrison would play lead and slide guitar parts for the Beatles. Harrison shouted this to encourage Lennon by comparing him to an iconic slide guitar player.

Harrison was increasingly becoming known for his slide playing. Whilst his encouragement to Lennon was very generous, by the time of his death, Harrison was as good as anyone at playing slide guitar:
